channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Pours Fighters Into Battle for Bakhmut
item.description: Part of Moscow’s strategy appears to be overwhelming Ukrainian defenses with waves of soldiers as it tries to gain its first significant victory in months.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: As China’s Covid Tsunami Recedes, Relief, Grief and Anxiety Follow
item.description: Officials say an onslaught of infections has slowed, and many people seem eager to move on. But fresh flare-ups could bring more illness and deaths.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A closed PCR testing booth sits idle in Shanghai. China’s Covid cases fell dramatically and case numbers peaked in December, according to Chinese public health officials.

item.title: Pope Francis Visits Congo: What to Know
item.description: The pope is planning to spend three days in the Democratic Republic of Congo, one of the most populous and most Catholic nations in Africa. While it has extensive natural riches, its people have long been buffeted by conflict and exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Internally displaced Congolese carry charcoal from the forest at the foot of Nyiragongo Volcano in Virunga National Park to the market in Kibati, this month.

item.title: Visiting Congo, Pope Francis Embraces the Poor and Exploited
item.description: The Central African country is wracked by war, poverty and environmental plunder — and it may be the future of the Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Maclean
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Francis arriving at N’djili International Airport in Kinshasa on Tuesday. He is the first pope to visit the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1985.

item.title: A Risky Trade in Ukraine Grows Riskier Amid the War
item.description: Russia’s invasion has disrupted the social services that help reduce harm to the women and men who sell sex, threatening public health.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Blinken Meets With Palestinian Leader After Surge in Violence
item.description: Following talks with Israeli officials in Jerusalem, the U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, met the Palestinian leadership in the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah amid a sharp rise in tensions in the region.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, left, visited the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, at the Palestinian Authority’s headquarters in Ramallah, part of a whirlwind regional tour coinciding with one of the deadliest months in the West Bank in several years.

item.title: Brexit Turns 3. Why Is No One Wearing a Party Hat?
item.description: The divorce between Britain and the European Union has become the dark thread that, to many, explains why Britain is suffering more than its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The International Monetary Fund said this week that Britain would be the world’s only major economy to contract in 2023, performing even worse than blacklisted Russia.

item.title: Support for Tunisian President Slipping After Parliament Vote
item.description: Turnout was meager in two rounds of voting for a Parliament stripped of much of its power, with most political parties barred from the elections.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ahmed Ellali
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Farouk Bouasker, president of the Tunisian electoral authority, announced some turnout results on Sunday for the second round of the parliamentary elections the capital, Tunis.

item.title: Sri Lanka Is Calm Again. That Doesn’t Mean Things Are Any Better.
item.description: After an economic collapse and political upheaval, Sri Lankans have become resigned to leaner meals and reduced horizons.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:credit: Jonathan Browning for The New York Times
item.media:description: Economic data paints a picture of starkly diminished lives in Sri Lanka, with inflation at nearly 60 percent.

item.title: France’s Pension Plan Strikes, Explained
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is forging ahead with plans to raise the legal age of retirement to 64, from 62, despite strikes, street demonstrations and a looming parliamentary battle.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Protesters in Nantes, France, during a nationwide strike in late January to voice their anger over proposed changes to the pension system.

item.title: Wagner Group May Have Committed War Crimes in Mali, UN Experts Say
item.description: Persistent reports point to “horrific executions” and other atrocities possibly committed by the Kremlin-affiliated mercenary force and the Malian military, according to human rights experts.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Wagner operatives at the Mopti airport, in central Mali, in February last year.

item.title: The Double Whammy Making Italy the West’s Fastest-Shrinking Nation
item.description: Italy’s population of elder Italians is soaring as its birthrate plummets, putting the country at the forefront of a global demographic trend that experts call the “silver tsunami.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Elisabetta Zavoli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Elderly and Children Together project in Piacenza, Italy, in December.

item.title: Golf Course or Housing? A Patch of Green Divides Hong Kong
item.description: The dispute over one of the city’s golf clubs exposes rare political friction for the elite in the new Hong Kong, where the establishment is torn between defending wealth and following Beijing’s wishes.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hong Kong Golf Club, in the Fanling area of the city, in 2018.

item.title: Gandhi’s Life in Photos, 75 Years After His Assassination
item.description: Known as the father of Indian independence, his concept of nonviolent resistance to fight injustice has inspired political movements around the world.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Matej Leskovsek
item.media:description: Mohandas K. Gandhi, affectionately called “Bapu,” or father, was killed on Jan. 30, 1948. He is still revered by many, his name a byword for a certain kind of virtue and action.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Europe’s economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Volkswagen factory in Dresden, Germany. Although there are signs that Europe may avoid a recession, the German economy contracted in the fourth quarter.

item.title: Administration Expected to Endorse Limited Drilling in Alaska Project
item.description: An environmental review expected soon would effectively signal that the Willow project proceed, according to people familiar with the report.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Environmentalists have criticized the project as counter to President Biden’s climate pledges. Supporters say it would create jobs and support the state financially.

item.title: Russia Floods Ukrainian City of Bakhmut With Troops
item.description: The battle in the eastern Ukraine city of Bakhmut is growing in importance, as both sides pour forces into the battle.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier last week in Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Charges Four in Connection With the Assassination of Haiti’s President
item.description: The decision to charge the men, considered to be ringleaders in the assassination plot, in the United States is an indication of the chronic dysfunction of the Haitian justice system.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: A portrait of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti at his memorial service in Port-au-Prince. The charges outlined a sprawling conspiracy to assassinate him.

item.title: Air Force Says Proposed Chinese-Owned Mill in North Dakota Is ‘Significant Threat’
item.description: A proposal for a corn mill, which had been welcomed as an economic development success, reflects just how much things have changed with Chinese investment proposals in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Lewis Ableidinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The proposed site of the Fufeng mill in Grand Forks, N.D.

item.title: U.S. Courts India as Technology Partner to Counter China
item.description: American and Indian officials are working toward new partnerships in defense technology, advanced telecom and semiconductors.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Biden said in May that they would begin talks about critical technology.

item.title: Netanyahu Juggles Competing Goals Over Palestinian Attacks
item.description: After a deadly week, Benjamin Netanyahu faces domestic calls for a harsh crackdown, and international pressure to moderate. It’s a familiar balancing act — but with one major difference.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arriving at a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Rebounds
item.description: Also, Russia’s resilient economy and Sri Lanka’s enduring struggle.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Villages across China are returning to normal.

item.title: Pakistan Grapples with Terrorist Attack That Left 101 Dead
item.description: The attack raised fears of a new wave of militancy from the Pakistani Taliban and sparked a heated debate over the government’s ability to meet that threat amid an economic and political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: The bombing of a mosque in Peshawar, Pakistan, knocked the city back in time, to an era where terrorist attacks were more prevalent.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Fails to Comply With START, a Nuclear Arms Treaty
item.description: The United States says Russia is not allowing American inspectors access to its arsenal to ensure compliance with the New START agreement, which the two nations renewed in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February last year by the Russian military under the command of President Vladimir V. Putin makes any further negotiations over arms control difficult.

item.title: In Photos: Pope Francis Visits Africa
item.description: The first pope to visit Africa in almost four decades began in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where the struggles of daily life are the very problems Francis has sought to highlight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving on Tuesday at N’djili International Airport in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Iran and Russia Move Toward Linking Their Banking Systems
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had long been cautious about deepening ties to Iran, but his calculus has changed during the course of the war.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: The Central Bank of the Islamic Republic of Iran in Tehran.

item.title: An Underused Covid Treatment
item.description: Doctors are now a major barrier to Paxlovid.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Paxlovid being manufactured in Ascoli, Italy, in 2021.

item.title: Russia Sidesteps Western Punishments, With Help From Friends
item.description: A surge in trade by Russia’s neighbors and allies hints at one reason its economy remains so resilient after sweeping sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The port at Vladivostok, Russia. Analysts estimate that Russia’s imports may have already recovered to prewar levels.

item.title: Russia’s economic growth suggests Western sanctions are having a limited impact.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Lukoil oil field in the Baltic Sea, Russia. A plan to cap the price of Russian oil exports is not expected to substantially curtail its energy revenue.

item.title: The Last Boeing 747 Leaves the Factory
item.description: The plane known as “Queen of the Skies” helped make air travel more affordable, but it has been supplanted by smaller, more efficient aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi, Meron Tekie Menghistab, Jovelle Tamayo and Lindsey Wasson
item.media:description: The first Boeing 747 at the plant in Washington State in September 1968.

item.title: Ukraine Redoubles Its Efforts to Obtain Fighter Jets
item.description: Ukraine’s allies have supplied Kyiv with an ever-growing list of weaponry, but many countries are wary of its recent requests for military jets.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: A Polish F-16 during a NATO exercise over Lask last year.

item.title: IMF Upgrades Global Economic Outlook as Inflation Eases
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said the world economy was poised for a rebound as inflation eases.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is projected to pick up the slack with output accelerating to 5.2 percent in 2023 from 3 percent in 2022.

item.title: Ukraine Urges Allies to Speed Up Delivery of Weaponry
item.description: “We have to make time our weapon,” President Volodymyr Zelensky declared as Ukrainians girded for an expected Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Alan Yuhas and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark during a visit to the city of Mykolaiv on Monday.

item.title: BBC Arabic Radio Airs Final Broadcast After 85 Years
item.description: The move came as part of cost-cutting measures under which the news service is also ending its radio programming in 10 other languages, including Persian, Chinese and Hindi.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:description: The BBC’s leaders said that the demands of an increasingly digital media landscape preceded their decision to scale down radio services.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Bombing in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Israel attacks Iran and the Adani Group fights fraud allegations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A suicide bomber struck Monday inside a mosque in the city of Peshawar, Pakistan, killing multiple people and wounding scores of worshippers.

item.title: NATO’s Chief Hints That South Korea Should Consider Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: NATO’s secretary-general, Jens Stoltenberg, urged South Korea to increase its support for Ukraine in the face of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary-general, speaking at the Chey Institute for Advanced Studies in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Turkey Raises Fresh Objections to Sweden and Finland’s NATO Bids
item.description: As he faces a tough fight for re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has been raising fresh objections to Sweden and Finland’s NATO membership bids.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan speaking in Ankara this month.

item.title: Boris Johnson Claims Putin Threatened to Fire a Missile at Him
item.description: The former British prime minister said the Russian leader made the remark during a phone call in the weeks before Putin’s forces invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Boris Johnson visiting Borodianka, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: How the Migrant Surge Is Playing Out Beyond the Southern U.S.
item.description: How the migrant surge is playing out far from the Southern U.S.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants arriving in New York City by bus from Texas in December.

item.title: Suicide Bombing at Pakistan Mosque Kills At Least 87
item.description: The mosque was nearly full when the attacker struck. By Tuesday, the toll stood at more than 100, the highest from a bombing in Pakistan in years.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Rescue workers treated a person wounded in the attack on Monday at a mosque frequented by police officers in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Blinken Meets Netanyahu at Turbulent Moment for Israel
item.description: The secretary of state and the Israeli leader had a ‘candid’ conversation amid deepening rifts over the Palestinians, Ukraine and a rightward shift by Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arriving for a joint news conference in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Baghdad Loses Green Space to Real Estate Boom
item.description: The problem is driving up temperatures in what is already one of the hottest cities in the world, where air-conditioning is a luxury only the rich can afford.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Yasmine Mosimann and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times

item.title: Some Wagner Convict Fighters in Ukraine Are Returning to Russia
item.description: Tens of thousands of inmates have joined a mercenary group fighting with the Kremlin’s decimated forces in Ukraine. Some of them are returning to civilian life with military training and, in many cases, battlefield traumas.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Ekaterina Bodyagina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A poster showing a member of the Russian military near the headquarters of the Wagner private military company in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A wave of violence in Israel and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Checking the damage after a fire in a village near Ramallah, in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: ‘Squid Game’ Actor Oh Young-soo Goes on Trial on Sex Crime Charges on Feb. 3
item.description: Oh Young-soo, the actor who portrayed a contestant in the popular Netflix series, is accused of inappropriately touching a South Korean woman in 2017.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Oh Young-soo arriving at a “Squid Game” event in Los Angeles in 2022.

item.title: Israel Launched Drone Attack on Iranian Facility, Officials Say
item.description: While the target’s purpose is unclear, the city of Isfahan is a major center of Iranian missile production, research and development.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A video capturing what is said to be the moment a drone hit a military factory in Isfahan, Iran.

item.title: As Israelis Grieve, Some Palestinians Exult, and Some Fear What’s Next
item.description: Two Palestinians shot a dozen Israelis, seven fatally, over the weekend. In the aftermath, the attackers’ relatives expressed a mixture of pride and dread.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Afif H. Amireh for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The Fallout from a Police Beating
item.description: Also, violence is flaring in Israel and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Times Square on Friday.

item.title: The Hunt for Nazi-Buried Treasure in a Dutch Village
item.description: The public release of a map from the 1940s has drawn fortune seekers with shovels and metal detectors to a small Dutch village. Not everyone is excited.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Annet Waalkens, an adviser at the Dutch National Archives in The Hague, with the file that includes the hand-drawn map by a Nazi soldier from the 1940s.

item.title: In the Fight Over Gas Stoves, Meet the Industry’s Go-To Scientist
item.description: Longstanding research shows the health dangers of gas-burning ranges. Utilities are turning to Julie Goodman, a toxicologist with a firm whose work raises questions about the science.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Dr. Goodman in an image from a 2021 video of a community meeting in Massachusetts regarding health concerns related to a fireworks facility.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Battle for Control of Villages Near the Key City of Bakhmut
item.description: The area is a flash point in an offensive that Moscow views as crucial for its goal of seizing the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on their way to the front line on Saturday in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak Fires Nadhim Zahawi, U.K. Conservative Party Chairman
item.description: In trying to bring “integrity” back to Downing Street, Rishi Sunak fired Nadhim Zahawi, the chairman of the governing Conservatives, over his personal tax affairs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Nadhim Zahawi leaving the Conservative Party offices in London last week.

item.title: Industry Gatekeepers
item.description: One company controls a wide swath of the concert industry, and lawmakers say music fans are paying the price.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu
item.media:description: A small number of people demonstrated outside the Senate office building during the hearing on Tuesday, some holding signs referencing the Taylor Swift ticket debacle.

item.title: Palestinian Man Fatally Shot as Violence Continues in Israel
item.description: Tensions and violence have gripped the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Jerusalem for days after an Israeli military raid on Thursday killed 10 people.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A Palestinian man checking damage on Sunday after a fire overnight in a village near Ramallah, in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Bus Plunge in Pakistan Kills at Least 40
item.description: The vehicle plunged down a ravine while traveling more than 300 miles from Quetta to the port city of Karachi.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: The wreckage of a passenger bus that plunged down a ravine on Sunday on the road from Quetta to Karachi, Pakistan.

item.title: Iran Says It Thwarted a Drone Attack on a Munitions Facility
item.description: The government did not say who was behind the attempted attack, but some Telegram channels affiliated with Iran’s Revolutionary Guards pointed the finger at Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Isfahan, a city in central Iran that was the target of a drone strike Saturday.

item.title: Hundreds Gather to Memorialize Renowned African Human Rights Lawyer
item.description: Thulani Maseko, who had pushed for years to end Africa’s last absolute monarchy, in Eswatini, formerly Swaziland, was killed in front of his wife and two young children.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Thulani Maseko in 2018 in Eswatini. He was killed a week ago.

item.title: Netherlands and Japan Said to Join U.S. in Curbing China’s Access to Chip Tech
item.description: A new agreement is expected to expand the reach of U.S. technology restrictions on China issued last year.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Workers at ASML in Veldhoven, Netherlands in 2018. The company’s products include advanced semiconductor printing machines.

item.title: Czech Republic Elects Petr Pavel President Over Andrej Babis
item.description: Petr Pavel, a political novice, defeated Andrej Babis, a populist business tycoon and former prime minister, in the first of several important European elections this year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Petr Pavel, the winner of the runoff vote in the Czech Republic’s presidential election, arriving on Saturday at his campaign headquarters in Prague.

item.title: Amid Spasm of Violence, Israel’s Far-Right Government Raises Risk of Escalation
item.description: Israel and the West Bank were gripped by violence this week. Its roots predate Israel’s new far-right government, but the government’s ministers and goals are fueling tensions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents on Saturday mourned the killing of seven people the night before by a Palestinian gunman outside a synagogue in East Jerusalem.
